Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the Stochastic Networks Conference to be held June 20-24, 2016 at the University of California, San Diego. Information about the conference is available through the conference website at

http://stochasticnetworks2016.ucsd.edu/

The 2016 Stochastic Networks Conference will provide a key forum for researchers from different quantitative disciplines, including mathematics, probability, operations research, computer science, electrical, mechanical and industrial engineering, to come together to hear and discuss the latest research developments related to stochastic networks. The program includes a broad spectrum of leading researchers amongst the invited speakers, including some speakers who are junior researchers, underrepresented minorities or women, as well as senior researchers. Participant support will help early career researchers, underrepresented minorities and women attend the conference to discuss and present their work.

Stochastic networks is a multifaceted area of research concerned with the modeling, stability, control, performance, approximation, and design of networks which are subject to the effects of stochastic variability. Research in this area is strongly motivated by applications in diverse domains of science and engineering. Examples of application areas include telecommunications, computer networks, high-tech manufacturing systems, service networks, social and biological networks, and health care management. The study of stochastic networks gives rise to challenging and subtle mathematical problems, whose solution often requires an innovative combination of ideas and techniques from several branches of mathematics. Many of the above aspects will be discussed at the conference.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported participant travel for the 2016 Stochastic Networks Conference held at the University of California, San Diego, June 20-24, 2016. This conference is part of a highly successful series of conferences, started in 1987, that are held at various locations around the world and now occur biennially. These international conferences bring together mathematicians and applied researchers to learn of the latest developments and new research directions in stochastic network modeling, analysis and applications.

Stochastic networks is a multifaceted area of research concerned with the modeling, stability, control, performance, approximation, and design of stochastic networks. It gives rise to challenging and subtle mathematical problems, whose solution often requires a combination of ideas and techniques from several branches of mathematics. Research in this area is strongly motivated by applications in diverse domains including telecommunications, computer networks, manufacturing systems, service networks, data storage and analysis, social and biological networks, and health care management.

The 2016 Conference featured 19 plenary talks on a diverse array of cutting edge topics in stochastic networks, including asymptotics and limit theorems for models of neural and protein assembly networks, community detection algorithms in graph models, dynamic control of stochastic models for healthcare management, learning in distributed information environments, optimal scheduling for data centers, and new techniques for analyzing infinite dimensional stochastic networks. This provided the participants with exposure to the latest developments and to key researchers in the field of stochastic networks, to inspire and inform their research. A poster session allowed participants an opportunity to present their own research, to hone their presentation skills and to gain feedback from experts in the field. 

The conference attracted 126 participants from a diverse array of disciplines in science and engineering who are interested in the modeling, analysis and applications of stochastic networks. This included researchers from the fields of Mathematics, Probability, Statistics, Electrical Engineering, Industrial Engineering, Computer Science, Operations Research, Management Science, and from Industrial and Government Research Labs (e.g., IBM, Microsoft, INRIA). The conference provided an opportunity for the 126 participants to learn of the latest research findings, to interact with researchers from a broad spectrum of different fields, and to present their own research to all. This benefitted a substantial number of early career researchers (nearly 60% of participants), as well as women and underrepresented minorities (25% of participants). Funds from this grant were used to partially support the travel expenses of 17 speakers and 31 other participants, amongst whom there were a total of 36 early career researchers and 13 women or underrepresented minorities. To provide open access to the conference materials, the conference website: http://stochasticnetworks2016.ucsd.edu contains titles and abstracts from the plenary talks and posters, as well as slides from many of the talks, presented at the 2016 Stochastic Networks Conference.
